title: CMYK and PMS
content: What is the CMYK for PMS 662?
author: dmfreeman

comments.content: According to my Pantone color bridge it's 100C 88M 20K

<cite>According to my Pantone color bridge it’s 100C 88M 20K</cite>

Ouch, I read that as 622.
Interesting, in the Euroscale version it's 100/84/0/20.

Through QuarkXPress - it breaks down as Patty has put it 100C 88M 20K. But that is for Pantone Color Solid Coated and Uncoated. (Though the coated is a bright purple and the uncoated is a dusty blue.)

In the actual Pantone Color Formula Guide on how to make the color it reads: (this would have to be for spot color)  
12 parts Pantone Blue 072 -70.6  
,75 part Pantone Black -4.4 and...  
4.5 parts Pantone Trans White -25

and that is the secret to why a PMS color that we see doesn't print looking like we thought it would. I checked with my Pantone Process Simulator - (great book shows you how each color prints on coated and uncoated stocks - and how far off the PMS guide really is) but sorry, it only goes to PMS 600.

If you are trying to get close in a print job to the swatch of 662 - you may want to add about 20y and up the k to 30 or 40 - (that from hubby, the retired color separator...)

P.S. Photoshop color picker says

100 cyan  
 90 magenta  
 20 yellow  
 16 black

<cite>Interesting, in the Euroscale version it’s 100/84/0/20.</cite>

Different environmental regulations lead to different ink formulae.

<cite>P.S. Photoshop color picker says</cite>

Never trust Adobe’s software conversions!

Those deep rich blues are one of the worst colors to accomplish in the CMYK gamut. They get muddy. I use Michael and Pat Rogondino's _Process Color Manual_ to estimate PMS conversions. There are a few blues in the manual that will come close to that, none of them will look exactly right on screen. Each has a shift one way or the other, so a compromise has to be made. My first pick was 100c 100m 10y 0k. My next look was 100c 90m 0y 10k.

Are you going to a printer? Ask them. Almost every production source I use has extensively tested their equipment and know the best color estimation their machinery will achieve.
